For those who are wondering how birds mate without penis...

Both male and female birds have what's known as a cloaca.

The cloaca is an internal chamber that ends in an opening, and through this opening, a bird's sex organs — testes or ovaries — discharge sperm or eggs. This same opening also serves a less-sexy purpose: the expulsion of urinary and digestive waste.

During mating seasons, the cloacal openings of both male and female birds swell, protruding slightly outside their bodies. When birds are feeling frisky, they rub their swollen cloacas together. The male's sperm, which has been stored in his cloaca, is deposited into the female's cloaca, where it travels up the chamber and eventually fertilizes an egg.
So that is why female birds are like they are.

It's interesting that there appears to be a correlation between which sex of a species has more traits that a purely to make them attractive to potential mates, and whether they have penises.

In most birds, where the females have complete control over mate selection, it's the males that have evolved to put more energy into being attractive to the opposite sex, through bright plumage and elaborate courtship behaviors. In primates, it's the females who have evolved to be sexier, with uncomfortable and inconvenient estrus genital swellings in the case of bonobos and chipanzees, and cumbersome breasts in case of humans, which stay large even when not breast feeding solely for the purpose of making the possessor more attractive to the opposite sex.

I wonder if this correlation applies to other species where females have complete control over mate selection, like many species of fish.

Slight tangent: The vast majority of fish species also do not have penises. But anyone who has ever been involved in the aquarium hobby probably knows about a family of fish species known generally as livebearers (because the females give birth to live young), like guppies, mollies, platys, and swordtails. Males from this family have a penis-like organ called a gonopodium that it uses to fertilize the female's eggs inside of her body. Also, in most (all?) shark species, the males have two (very obvious) penis-like organs called claspers.

Contrary to the point at 4:20
Penis and urethra length actually prevents infection. This is apparent because males usually have less infections than females, whereas a shorter urethra allows bacteria to pass more easily to the internal organs.
I suspect that females survive copulations better without deep penetration and then carry the sperm of males with smaller penises, so this trait is carried.
It wouldn't be a female choice, just an evolutionary drive. The fete of the male would be unimportant, only if he has little involvement in rearing offspring, which is not usually the case.
Perhaps this leads to stronger bacteria control in the male, rather than relying on a long penis/urethra to prevent deep infections.
